article.title: Alexander_Anderson_%28mathematician%29
article.paragraph: other peopleAlexander AndersonAlexander Anderson(circa1582,Aberdeencirca1620,Paris) was aScottish peopleScottishmathematician.
article.heading: Life
article.paragraph: He was born inAberdeen, possibly in 1582, according to a print which suggests he was aged 35 in 1617.Wikisource:Anderson, Alexander (1582-1619?) (DNB00)It is unknown where he was educated, but it is likely that he initially studied writing and philosophy (the "belles lettres") in his home city of Aberdeen.cite bookThe General Biographical Dictionary: Containing an Historical and Critical Account of the Lives and Writings of the Most Eminent Persons in Every Nation: Particularly the British and Irish; from the Earliest Accounts to the Present TimeChalmersA.1812J. Nicholshttp://books.google.co.uk/books?id175–176

He then went to theMainland Europecontinent, and was a professor of mathematics in Paris by the start of the seventeenth century.There he published or edited, between the years 1612 and 1619, variousgeometricandalgebraictracts.sfnChisholm1911He described himself as having "more wisdom than riches" in the dedication ofVindiciae Archimedis(1616).

He was first cousin of David Anderson of Finshaugh, a celebrated mathematician, and David Anderson's daughter was the mother of mathematicianJames Gregory (mathematician)James Gregory.cite bookThe Edinburgh encyclopædia conducted by David Brewster, with the assistance of gentlemen eminent in science and literatureBrewsterD.1832J. and E. Parkerhttp://books.google.co.uk/books?id41
article.heading: Work
article.paragraph: He was selected by the executors ofFranois Viteto revise and edit Vite's manuscript works. Vite died in 1603, and it is unclear if Anderson knew him, but his eminence was sufficient to attract the attention of the dead man's executors.cite bookLives of illustrious and distinguished Scotsman, forming a complete Scottish biographic dictionaryChambersR.1841Blackie and Sonhttp://books.google.co.uk/books?id37Anderson corrected and expanded upon Vite's manuscripts, which extended known geometry to thenew algebra, which used general symbols to represent quantities.
article.heading: Publications
article.paragraph: The known works of Anderson amount to six thin quarto volumes, and as the last of them was published in 1619, it is probable that the author died soon after that year, but the precise date is unknown.sfnChisholm1911He wrote other works that have since been lost.From his last work it appears he wrote another piece, "A Treatise on the Mensuration of Solids,"cite bookA Biographical Dictionary of Eminent Scotsmen, in Four VolsChambers, R.Thomson, T.1856v. 1Blackiehttp://books.google.co.uk/books?id533 October 2014and copies of two other works,Ex. Math.andStereometria Triangulorum Sphricorum, were in the possession of Sir Alexander Hume until the after the middle of the seventeenth century.
